p:
Caesium-potassium-antimonides are known to crystallise in a cubic crystal struture with 16 atoms in the unit cell
19– 21 . The structure of Cs 3Sb first resolved in the pioneering study by Jack and Wachtel
19 is characterised by 8 sites occupied by an equal number of Cs atoms and by additional 8 sites with random Cs and Sb occupations. In our first-principles calculations we consider an idealised FCC crystal structure for stiochiometric Cs 3Sb, Cs 2KSb, and CsK 2Sb (see Fig. 1a–c) also adopted in previous theoretical studies
13, 22 . In this FCC lattice, the Sb atoms are located at the origin of the unit cell with Wycoff coordinates (0,0,0), while the alkali species are found at (1/2, 1/2, 1/2) and ±(1/4, 1/4, 1/4). We denote these sites as A 2, A 1, and A 3, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1a. From a crystallographic viewpoint, A 1 and A 3 represent equivalent sites. In Cs 3Sb, where all these positions are occupied by Cs atoms, there are two inequivalent Cs atoms in the unit cell. We consider Cs 2KSb and CsK 2Sb structures such that the two alkali species occupy inequivalent sites, as visualised in Fig. 1b,c.
